m2.description: animal pendant; highly calcified, opaque ivory jade, little remnant of the original green color, traces of red pigment; Huang shaped pendant with bird beak, tiger body and a fish tail; lei-wan design around eye

m2.title: Tiger
m2.description: The decor of incised lines and spirals on this animal recall those on the Middle Chou water buffalo, Karlgren Number 90 (50.46.113). It should be noted, however, that the spirals on shoulders and hind quarters area here centered by a raised ring with turquoise inlay. These decor figures might point to a similar epoch were it not for certain details that are a clear indication of a later date. The rope pattern around the eyes, on the eyebrows, the fetlocks, and on the dragon decorating the socket, as well as the granulation on the front of the ears and the head of the dragon, point to the Early Huai Style Period. The socket on the back suggests that the tiger served as a podium. Patina bluish- green.
m2.comments: This tiger with socket clearly served as the base for an upright support of some sort. Treatment of certain details like the rope patterns around the eyes, on the socket and eyebrows, and fetlocks and the granulation pattern on the ears indicate a date around 500 B.C.E.

m2.title: Archaic Animal Pendant

m2.title: Winged dragon, one of a pair
m2.description: The sculpture quality of these dashing beasts is admirably conveyed by their carriage, the proud pose of their heads, and the almost arrogant suppleness of their bodies. The forceful comma-shapes of the tails and their jaunty tufts, as well as the double-rope pattern on the mustachios, give ample proof that, in spite of the scale that, in these creatures must be dated later than Middle Chou. Patina grey-green
m2.comments: The sculptural quality of these dashing beasts is conveyed by their stances, the proud carriage of their heads, and the apparent agility of their bodies. The forceful comma-shaped tails and their jaunty tufts, as well as the double-rope patterns on the moustaches, are typical elements of Warring States period art.

m2.title: Pendant in the Form of a Hare

m2.title: Yazhang ceremonial scepter
m2.medium: Dark olive-green jade with light brown clouds
m2.description: Dark olive green jade with light brown clouds. Central perforation from one side at the stem of the handle.
m2.comments: Known as yazhang, this type of jade originated during the Longshan culture (c. 2500–c. 2000 BCE) in northeast China and was used as a ceremonial scepter until the Western Zhou dynasty. Yazhang scepters vary in their form and scale according to culture and geography. This yazhang has a long, narrow blade that curves slightly and ends in a nearly symmetrical, lunar-shaped cutting edge. On the other end, between the rectangular handle and blade, pairs of ornate teeth project beyond the edges of the scepter and are connected by incised horizontal bands. A central perforation has been drilled from one side at the stem of the handle. In its scale, shape, and toothed projections, this scepter resembles those from the late period of the Erlitou culture, which flourished in the central plains of China.

m2.title: Belt Hook
m2.description: ivory jade, traces of earthlike substance.

m2.title: Ceremonial Ge Dagger
m2.description: Calcified white jade chi-ku-pai, traces of earthlike substance.

m2.title: Covered zhou ritual food vessel
m2.description: The bowl, in the broad and bulky shape of the Huai style, is supported by four human figures with horned animals' heads. The rigid ring handles have an out-curving lower projection which, with the outer bend of the ring, forms a dragon with a curled-up tail. This dragon has a head like a t'ao-t'ieh. The ring-shaped top of the lid, adorned with a triple-strand plait pattern in openwork, is affixed to the lid with a row of small props. The close affinity of this vessel to one almost exactly similar in the Royal Ontario Museum is interesting in view of the fact that the latter is known to have come from the Kin-ts'un tombs (Ca.450-230 B.C.). Patina green.

m2.title: Gui food vessel
m2.description: The name Kuei for this vessel type is well established in the early literature. The surfaces of the vessel are divided into four vertical panels by four flanges on the foot, two flanges and two handles on the body. These narrow, thin flanges contrast contrast sharply with the heavy handles and their massive bovine heads. The principal figures in the decor, executed in low relief except for the strongly protruding eyes, are so covered with adorning lines that they tend to merge with the ground of squared spirals. In the foot belt are rudimentary t'ao-t'ieh masks, the central line formrd by two of the flanges, and two consecutive, head-turning dragons with C-shaped horns. The mask t'ao-t'ieh on the belly, with ordinary features strongly detatched, is flanked by vertical dragons. The flanges form the centers of two such t'ao-tieh, the handles of two other masks in which the face (nose and hooked forehead shield) has been cleft, leavint an interstice as broad as the handles between the two halves. This space under the handles is decorated with a bovine head in flat relief, thus creating a small t'ao-t'ieh inside a larger one. The neck belt displays dragons with oversized beaks. Patina blackish.
m2.comments: This vessel is among the earliest gui with looped handles, which emerged in the latest period of the Shang dynasty. The surfaces of the vessel are divided into four vertical panels by four flanges on the foot and two flanges and two handles on the body. These narrow, thin flanges contrast sharply with the heavy handles and their massive bovine heads. The taotie mask on the belly is flanked by vertical dragons. The principal figures in the surface decor, executed in low relief except for the strongly protruding eyes, are so covered with embellished lines that they tend to merge with the ground of squared spirals. The vessel bears a single script inscription, “Shi,” which stands as an insignia for a clan. In recent years, a large number of bronzes unearthed in modern Shandong bear the same inscription, dating from the late Shang to early Western Zhou, thus revealing the location of this powerful clan whose members served in the court of the Shang king. It seems that the word originally referred to an official title. It was later adopted as the insignia of the clan whose members held this position for several generations.

m2.title: Dragon-head Finial
m2.department: Chinese, South and Southeast Asian Art
m2.medium: Green jade with traces of red pigment
m2.description: green jade with traces of red pigment; front of finial shows profile of dragon head forked prong horns and long mane.

m2.title: Chang Scepter
m2.description: Green jade with light ochre spots. Termed a 'Chang' or ritual jade.
m2.comments: The innately beautiful bluish-green color of this ritual scepter, with its russet inclusions combines with a simplicity and elegance of form to elevate this ancient object to a realm of aesthetic grace that is timeless. Ceremonial weapons and implements represent some of the earliest Chinese jades as the origins of this type of object lies in the Neolithic period. It was largely during the early Bronze Age however, in Shang and Western Zhou, that some utilitarian weapon types evolved into a limited group of particular shapes executed in precious jade that held ritual significance in important political and social ceremonies. Most of the ceremonial jade scepters that have survived were buried in tombs suggesting they also held significance for the spirit in the afterlife. Ancient bronze inscriptions record the use of land and jade as gifts between rulers and dependents. It is possible that the Chang scepters this type may have been part of the insignia used in rites connected with the land.

m2.title: Bixi Disc Pendant
m2.description: green jade with brown clouds. Pair of ch'ih (hornless dragons) in high relief on surface of oblong pendant with central opening.

m2.title: Bixi Disc Pendant
m2.department: Chinese, South and Southeast Asian Art
m2.description: white jade, traces of earthlike substance. Flat oval pendant with prowling tigerlike creature in openwork. Incised comma-spiral pattern on front and cloud pattern on reverse.

m2.title: Stone Seal
m2.department: Chinese, South and Southeast Asian Art
m2.description: Cat, white translucent jade; L.1-1/4 in., W. 5/8 in., H. 11/16 in. (Previously identified as a dog).
m2.comments: Used by literati to impress their personal marks on documents and works of art, seals were among the most important scholar's implements. The literati often carved the legends themselves. Bronze and jade were commonly used for seals before the Yüan dynasty (1280–1368), but these materials proved too hard to be carved by anyone but professionals. In the Ming dynasty, soapstone became the preferred material of the literati. Scholars readily carved the soft material in their personal calligraphic styles. Like literati paintings, seals expressed the taste and personality of their owners. The squared, angular characters and simple, forceful calligraphy in these examples were inspired by Han dynasty (2nd century BCE–2nd century CE) script, which along with bronze inscriptions and other early styles of calligraphy was studied and emulated by the wen ren. The tortoise at the top of each seal often appeared in Han dynasty seals. It symbolized longevity, strength, and endurance, traits associated with the scholar.

m2.title: Hu Trapezoidal Ceremonial Blade
m2.description: Black jade.

m2.title: Seal
m2.department: Chinese, South and Southeast Asian Art
m2.description: white and black jade

m2.title: Pan water basin
m2.description: The Pan of the Yin era do not usually have handles; those of Early Chou usually, but not invariably, do. The division of the two decor belts, neck and foot, is achieved in the former by an unusually realistic bovine head, and in the latter by a thin flange. The decor ground is of spirals of varying size throughout. The bird in the foot belt, of the regular type, displays one odd variation. The long tail is, as usual, cleft in two parts, the lower descending, the upper rising in a long loop. In this instance, however, the shorter part is modified so as to resemble the leg of the bird, giving the impression that the bird has one front and one hind leg. The tuft in the middle, whee the tail goes out from the boky, is a common feature (cf. vessel 50.46.19, Karlgren #33). The winged dragon in the upper belt has a small vertial crest and a big bottle horn with a fingerleaf top that has an eye in the center of the leaf. Patina grey-green in neck and foot belts.

m2.title: Dagger-axe (ge)
m2.description: The tang of this weapon displays the same unexplained dented contour as that on 50.46.21. The shape has been modified through the lengthening of the lower lug into an extended support along the shaft. A long slender leaf follows the curve of the blade. Above this decor, toward the base of the tang, is the eye and rolled-up nose of a dragon's head, its plastically lifted hord decorated with snakes.

m2.title: Bird
m2.description: It is probable that this bird served as an accessory member of some object, possibly a piece of furniture or a large vessel, in as much as the ring in the beak is evidently a handle. Whatever its purpose, the bird is a magical creature, having crest, ears and horns. The broad sweep of its wings, adorned with scales, make it a beautiful one as well. The shoulder line is emphasized by a big comma figure in high, rounded relief. patina green.

m7.title: Mao Tse Tung [Mao Zedong]
m7.description:
Through the upheaval of the Cultural Revolution (1966-1976) Mao Zedong aimed to reinvigorate Communism in China and eliminate traditional urban class differences. A 'saturation campaign' of visual propaganda was a primary vehicle for disseminating the new ideologies. Themes and form were rigidly prescribed and the idealised figures were often copied from source books.
Mao Zedong's personal aim behind the Cultural Revolution was to bolster his own position within the Communist Party. Posters helped to propagate the cult and here he is seen literally as the central subject. Chairman Mao badges and posters offered a means for people to 'own' the cult and demonstrate their allegiance.

m7.title: Colt
m7.description:
Xu Beihong (1895-1953) was an important early pioneer in the introduction of Western art to China and in the adaptation of it to Chinese character. As one of the most acclaimed painters and educators in modern China, he influenced the development of 20th-century Chinese painting. 

Xu was born in a village in Yixing, Jiangsu province. He studied painting in his hometown and Shanghai before having an opportunity to go to Europe. In the period from 1919 to 1927, he studied at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts in Paris, acquiring a solid foundation in the Western academic tradition. On returning to China, Xu became a powerful force for the introduction of Western art through his teaching, writing and exhibitions; his influence was rivalled only by Liu Haisu and Lin Fengmian. After 1949, with the founding of the People’s Republic, he settled in Beijing and became Director of the new Central Academy of Fine Arts and Chairman of the National Artists’ Association. 

Horse is Xu's favourite subject matter. This painting reflects the artist's principal artistic concern, namely, to bring together the Western academic tradition of painting and Chinese aesthetics through ink techniques. The work was made in summer 1944, shortly before the artist had a medical operation. It was given by him to Miss Ellen Wilkinson (1891-1947), a prominent member of the Labour cabinet in Clement Attlee's government. It was given to the V&A by her sister, Miss Ann Wilkinson, after her death.

m7.title: X-TIGI S18
m7.description:
More power in my pocket

In 2015, this phone became a bestseller in Accra, Ghana. It has a long battery life and functions as a power bank for smartphones and other devices, crucial in a city and digital innovation hub where blackouts are frequent and longlasting. The phone comes with an LED lamp attachment and three sim card slots to enable the user to access three phone numbers at the same time.

The object sits in the 'Housing and Living' section of the Design 1900-Now gallery opened in June 2021.

m17.title: Countryside in China
m17.description: Born in Fujian Province, Liu Kang (1911-2004) received his formal training in Shanghai Academy of Fine Art, where he was exposed to Chinese paintings. In 1928, he went to Paris where he was influenced by art movements such as Fauvism and Post-Impressionism. Not only was he one of Singapore’s pioneer artists, he was also a leading figure in the Society of Chinese Artists and the Singapore Art Society. In 1970, he was awarded the Public Service Star for his contributions in the field of art.After leaving Paris in 1933, Liu returned to teach at his alma mater. He often took his students on outdoor painting trips and this painting could have resulted from one of the trips.

m17.title: Great Wall of China
m17.description: Born in Fujian Province, Liu Kang (1911-2004) received his formal training in Shanghai Academy of Fine Art, where he was exposed to Chinese paintings. In 1928, he went to Paris where he was influenced by art movements such as Fauvism and Post-Impressionism. Not only was he one of Singapore’s pioneer artists, he was also a leading figure in the Society of Chinese Artists and the Singapore Art Society. In 1970, he was awarded the Public Service Star for his contributions in the field of art.Liu often travelled within and outside Singapore, and as he did so, he painted the places he visited. China was a place of inspiration for Liu and here, the grandeur and magnificence of the iconic Great Wall as it traverses difficult terrain, is depicted.

m17.title: Portrait of Eugene Chen
m17.description: Born in China in 1906, Georgette Chen Li Ying received her art education in Paris, New York as well as in Shanghai. Chen’s artistic oeuvre can be divided into three phases, French Period (1927-1933); China-Hong Kong Period (1934-1948) and Penang-Singapore Period (1949-1980). Immensely inspired by her surroundings she produced still lifes, portraits and landscapes from each phase. Settling in Singapore in 1954, she taught at the Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts till her retirement in 1980. Regarded as a Pioneer Artist of Singapore who developed the Nanyang Style, she was awarded the Cultural Medallion in 1982. Chen passed away in 1993 in Singapore.One of several portraits of Eugene Chen in the SAM collection, this one shows the first Foreign Minister of the Republic of China, deep in thought with a book in hand.
m17.comments: Donated by Estate of Georgette Chen Liying (Deceased)

m17.title: Bird on Pine
m17.medium: Chinese ink and colour on paper
m17.description: The spirit of the Lingnan School spread beyond China and lived well into the post-war period as a result of Zhao Shao’ang’s efforts. Zhao showed great virtuosity in this bold composition. The gnarled surface of the pine tree is effectively conveyed through the variation of ink and strokes. Zhao expressed his admiration for the pine tree in the inscription by praising its resilience and magnificence despite undergoing the ravages of time and the environment.
m17.comments: From the Xiang Xue Zhuang Collection in memory of Dr Tan Tsze Chor

m22.title: Religious Verse
m22.description: This is the only extant calligraphy by the Chinese priest Longyan Dezhen. This calligraphy was created in response to a request from the Japanese priest Mumu Issei, who studied in China.

m22.title: Melon and Insects
m22.medium: Hanging scroll; ink and color on paper
m22.description: Piling, Changzhou in Jiangsu province was the center of insect and grasses paintings in China. This work was an early clue for scholars in the confirmation of the existence of insect and grasses paintings in Piling.

m22.title: Clay Figure of an Officer
m22.description: It was customary during China's Northern Wei dynasty to place large numbers of clay figurines in tombs. This figurine, with its emphasized smooth flatness and beautiful expression, is typical of Northern Wei figurines.

m22.title: Four-storied Pavilion in Green Glaze
m22.description: Green glazed ceramics were popular during the Han dynasty. This work reflects the lifestyles of that period.

m22.title: Squared
m22.description: This bronze is small in scale and extremely finely finished. This type of bronze vessel was used in ancient China to offer wine or food to the gods.

m22.title: Double-Ram
m22.country: China  probably Hunan province, 13th-11th centuries B.C.
m22.description: This form, with a ram on each side of a cylindrical wine vessel (

m22.title: Zun
m22.description: This bronze vessel is thought to have been excavated from the tomb of a Shang dynasty king. Production of this vessel shape began around that period and continued across the millennia to China`s last imperal dynasty, the Qing.

m22.title: Flower Vase with Handles in the Shape of Elephant Heads
m22.country: China Southern Song - Ming dynasties, 12th-14th centuries
m22.description: There are many examples of Chinese bronzes from the Song dynasty through the Qing dynasty that have been used in Japan as flower vases. This work was used as a flower vase at a flower exhibition held in 1665. This flower vase was owned by the Tokugawa shogunal family.

m22.title: Mirror with Parkeets and Grapes Design
m22.description: This mirror dates to the early Tang dynasty. The grape and vining plant motif was brought to China from West Asia during the Han dynasty, becoming a poplar decorative motif from the early Tang to the high Tang. Grapes are considered an auspicious motif symbokizing fertility.

m22.title: Three Squared
m22.description: This ritual bronze vessels created during China's Shang dynasty are extremely rare example of a set made up of three pieces.

m22.title: Fragment of
m22.description: Various types of Buddhist ecclesiastical cloths handed down in Hōryū-ji are known. They are characterized by the bright red ground.

m22.title: Box with Landscape and a Pavilion Design
m22.description: Carved lacquer wares were highly prized in Japan from the Kamakura through Muromachi periods. Examples, as here, of Yongle era carved lacquer, were particularly desirable amongst such carved lacquer works.

m22.title: Tray with Peony Design
m22.description: This tray is made of so-called carved red lacquer.  Large peonies adorns the middle of the tray. The back of the tray is inscribed in needle carving script " Da ming Yongle nianzhi (Made in the great Ming dynasty, Yongle era) ".  This tray was made for use by the Ming imperial court.

m22.title: Box with a Pavilion and Figures Design
m22.medium: Lacquer on wood with mother-of-pearl inlay
m22.description: This mother-of-pearl box was made in the Yuan dynasty. Thin shells were cut into small complex shapes and used to create the decoration. The top of the box lid is decorated with a scene of immortal women enjoying a banquet.

m22.title: Bowl with Three White Fruits Design
m22.description: This bowl with pale brown color glaze has a slightly turned out mouth rim. Three places on the torso are marked with three fruit motifs (pomegranate, peach and lychee) left in white reserve.

m22.title: Bowl with Three Fishes Design
m22.description: Three fish motifs in red glaze are set against a pure white porcelain ground. Close examination reveals that the fish details were worked in incised lines.

m22.title: Dish with Magnolia Design
m22.description: This dish is decorated with white magnolia branches and blossoms set against the blue ground, which gives the entire dish a refreshingly clear mood.

m22.title: Dish with Flower Basket Design
m22.description: This thickly potted flat dish has its rim turned back. A flowers motif fills the interior surface in fine-grained. The geometrical pattern is somehow reminiscent of so-called

m22.title: Large Dish with Flower and Plant Design
m22.description: During the early Ming dynasty the trend for large-scale wares made in either underglaze blue porcelain or celadon was continued from the Yuan dynasty. While the work is unsigned, it is thought to date from the Yongle era.

m22.title: Vase in Meiping Style with Dragon and Phoenix Design
m22.description: Yuan dynasty underglaze blue porcelain wares were made for export to Islamic countries. Many of these wares were large in scale and had decorative motifs that covered the entire vessel.

m22.title: Tea Container, named
m22.medium: China Southern Song - Yuan dynasties, 13th-14th centuries
m22.country: China Southern Song - Yuan dynasties, 13th-14th centuries
m22.description: This

m22.title: Vase with Cylindrical Body, named
m22.description: This vase has a hole cut into its back surface and is fitted with a metal attachment so that it can be used as a hanging flower vase. This work is a masterpiece of the so-called

m22.title: Vase with Tall Neck
m22.description: The so-called "bamboo shoot" shaped vase type has a long neck and a swelling torso base surrounded by several protruding bands. This vase has a particularly pleasing glaze tone and shape, and is thus considered one of the finest examples of this vase type.

m22.title: Foliated Dish with Carved Lotus Flower Design
m22.description: Overall the bowl is shaped like a flower. The interior of the bowl is covered with a deeply etched, so-called "one-sided carving" lotus blossom design.

m22.title: Large Jar with Applied Ornaments
m22.country: China Northern Qi - Sui dynasties, 6th century
m22.description: This large jar coated in a green glaze has palmettes, celestial women and other designs attached to its surface, which emphasize its exotic West Asian style.

m22.title: Jar with Chicken-headed Spout
m22.description: This jar has a chicken-headed spout and was a new vessel type that appeared at the Yuezhou Kilns. Celadon glazes in either a dark green color or yellowish tinged color characterize early examples of the type.

m22.title: Head of a Seated Bosatsu (Bodhisattva)
m22.description: This is the head of a Bodhisattva image that originally decorated the north wall of Cave 21 at the Tianlongshan caves in China's Shanxi province. The face with its sense of mass reveals the typical sculptural style of the Tang dynasty, considered the pinnacle of cave creation at the Tianlongshan cave site.

m22.title: Eleven-headed
m22.description: This image is one of a group of relief-carved stone Buddhist plinths from Huatasi temple, Xian (also known as Baoqingsi). The symmetrically arranged body and the flowing drapery lines are particularly beautiful, making this an important fundamental piece in the study of Chinese early Tang period Buddhist sculpture.

m22.title: Standing Buddha
m22.description: This work is considered a major masterpiece of large-scale marble Buddhist sculpture made in the late Nortern Qi dynasty. The complete state of the image's dais is also noteworthy. The unusually large head and slight smile give a strong impression to its viewers.

m22.title: Seated Sakyamuni and Prabhutaratna
m22.description: This is a typical example of the two-figure Buddhist images created during the Northern Wei dynasty. The inscription explains that this was created as part of a memorial service for deceased parents. The powerful carving and size of the work make it a renowned example of its kind.

m22.title: Budai and Jiang Mohe in Discussing Buddhism
m22.artist: By Yintuoluo, with inscription by Chishi Fanqi
m22.description: The unusual painting style of this work blends lines drawn with a worn brush with dark black ink, while the figure expression is Zen-like in its extraordinary rendition.

m22.title: Sparrows on Bamboo in the Rain
m22.description: Two sparrows sit on a dead tree branch, slowing getting soaked in the rain. A sense of dampness pervades the painting.

m22.title: Fishing Village at Sunset
m22.description: This landscape of a fishing village at dusk shows a splendid use of the diverse effects possible in ink painting. This is a masterpiece by Muqi, a Zen priest-painter of late Southern Song dynasty.

m22.title: Mountain Landscape at Sunset
m22.artist: By Ma Lin, with inscription by Empelor Lizong
m22.medium: Hanging scroll; ink and slight color on silk
m22.description: This is a superb example of Southern Song dynasty academic landscape painting, created in a simple composition based on diagonal lines and cautiously exact brushwork.

m22.title: Quail
m22.medium: Hanging scroll; ink and color on silk
m22.description: The intricacy of the depiction and carefully arranged composition give this quail painting a sense of realism. This work is renowned as a major example of Song dynasty bird and flower painting.
